Award.AwardTitle: ECR: Strategic Integration of MOOCs into Graduate and Professional STEM Programs in 21st Century Research Universities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
EHR Core Research
Workforce Development

The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign is conducting a workforce development capacity building project that is designed to advance the strategic integration of Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) into graduate and professional STEM programs in 21st century research universities by setting the stage for robust research studies. The PI proposes to conduct a workshop to explore pedagogical issues such as the effectiveness of flipped classrooms merged with MOOCs through a rigorous experimental design, data collection, and analysis process. The workshop will provide a platform for thought leaders and key stakeholders, including employers, to discuss paths for incorporating these emerging educational portals and platforms into the existing fabric of universities. They will discuss the findings of the workshop and identify research questions about technology, pedagogy, widespread implementation, and specific implications for graduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were to: 1) assess the quality of Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) offered by the University of Illinois on the Coursera platform; 2) compare the effectiveness of MOOC instruction to on-campus instruction and MOOC-integrated courses; 3) assess faculty, staff, and administrator perceptions of MOOCs and MOOC-integrated classes; and 4) disseminate findings and questions with a wide audience of stakeholders in MOOCs. This was accomplished through a series of four tasks:

Task 1: Review of Literature – Researchers identified and assessed the quality of extant research and literature on MOOCs and MOOC-integrated classes.

Task 2: Multivariate learning outcomes testing of MOOCs – this task assessed participants in MOOCs as well as those in similar on-campus courses and those which integrate MOOC technologies to traditional courses. The task revolved around addressing two main research questions: Q1) What is the effect on instruction, engagement and learning outcomes for on-campus students when STEM courses integrate MOOC students? and Q2) How do engagement and learning differ for face-to-face students versus MOOC students within the same course? The methodology called for comparing the outcomes of on-campus and MOOC course to see if outcomes differ when the same or similar content is offered in two different settings. Data collection has included pre- and post-course attitude and behavioral surveys of students in MOOCs, real-time observation of Coursera MOOC activities, and data collection through Coursera of student performance. Multivariate outcomes testing of MOOC participants/students was enacted on three course iterations: Introduction to Sustainability (Spring 2014); Emergence of Life (Fall 2014); and a second Introduction to Sustainability iteration (Fall 2014).

Task 3: Assessing perceptions of the effectiveness of MOOCs –MOOCs are a new and potentially disruptive innovation in higher education, and yet little has been done to investigate the level of understanding and acceptance of these technologies among faculty, staff, administrators, and students. This was realized through a campus-wide survey of University of Illinois instructional staff. The development of the survey involved conducting interviews with selected faculty and staff with knowledge of MOOCs to determine appropriate questioning, gain an understanding of the key issues related to MOOCs at a research university, and to examine the particular nuances related to MOOCs in STEM fields. The campus-wide survey of University of Illinois instructional staff involved a total of 420 responses, with a high level of engagement among staff who opened the e-mail.

Task 4: Dissemination and interactive dialogue on MOOCs with national and international experts – including policy makers in MOOCs, online education, and higher education access. This was enacted through a workshop (Spring 2015) that brought together experts, scholars, and leaders at universities in the U.S. and beyond to discuss project findings, significant issues in MOOC development and implementation, and to dialogue about future needs. The research team successfully developed and implemented a workshop at the University of Illinois, entitled "Strategic Integration of MOOCs in Research Universities", which occurred May 12-13, 2015. The event was attended by approximately 80 individuals; incudling participants from research universities, educational organizations, foundations, and state and national governmental organizations both in the U.S. and Europe.  At the workshop, the research team shared major results from this NSF-sponsored project to an international audience. A white paper was developed based on research findings and workshop proceedings, and was disseminated to workshop attendees and beyond in the fall of 2015.
